Parameters.Text: We would like to ask a few questions about your mental health and treatment history. Answers to these personal questions are kept confidential, but they help us improve Hoos Think Calmly by figuring out for whom it works well.
Are you currently struggling with any of the following mental disorders? Please select all that apply.

Buttons: I am not struggling with a mental disorder

Parameters.Text: Are you currently receiving help for any of the previously listed disorders? Please select all that apply, or "I am not receiving help".

Buttons: Therapy:Therapy (talking with a trained professional)/n/nExamples:: Psychologist, licensed mental health practitioner (LMHC), school counselor, social worker, marriage and family therapist, group therapist
Prescription: Prescription medications/n/nExamples:: Psychiatrist, medical doctor
Social:Seeking social support (talking with non-professionals)/n/nExamples:: Teacher, family member, friend, religious leader, coach
SelfHelp:Self-guided help/n/nExamples:: Self-help book, blogs, online intervention (other than MindTrails), mobile applications

Parameters.Text:
Has therapy (talking with a trained professional) been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful

Have prescription medications been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful

Has seeking social support (talking with non-professionals) been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful

Has self-guided help been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful

Has over-the-counter medications and/or supplements been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful

Has what you specified in "other" been helpful? 

1 = Not helpful at all
4 = Somewhat helpful
7=Extremely helpful
There are many reasons people do not receive help. Why are you not receiving mental health treatment? Please select all that apply.

Buttons: I don't think a prescription medication would help me
I don't like the idea of taking prescription medication
I can't afford to pay for treatmentI don't want to talk to a mental health professional (e.g., a therapist)
I don't think that a mental health professional can help meIt is hard to find a mental health professional near me
I don't know how to find a mental health professionalI am embarrassed to seek treatment
I don't want to be asked to face my fears (e.g., not wanting to interact with a spider for a person with spider fear)
I don't want to talk about my feelings
I had treatment previously and didn't find it helpful

Parameters.Text: In the past two months, have there been any changes to your mental health treatment? Check all that apply.

Buttons: My prescriber changed my prescription dose
I started a prescription medication I stopped a prescription medication

Parameters.Text:
In this brief exercise, you will read several short stories.

Please read each one carefully and try to imagine yourself in the situation.

The last word of each story is incomplete. Click on the missing letter to complete the word.

After you correctly complete the word, you will be asked a question about the story. Answer the question based on the information in the story.
You are in the lobby of your friend's new apartment building.  You press the button to the elevator to go up. The building looks old.  As you get on the elevator you think about its...

Buttons: Clubs and Organizations (e.g., cultural groups, volunteering)
Office for Equal Opportunity and Civil Rights (EOCR)
Office of Graduate and Postdoctoral Affairs
Office of the Dean of Students (ODOS)

Parameters.Text: Did you think about the elevator's safety?
Your friend asks you to give a speech at her wedding reception. You prepare some remarks and when the time comes, get to your feet. As you speak, you notice some people in the audience start to...
Does the audience laugh when you speak?

You are currently working as a contractor for a company. Once this job is finished, you will be without employment until you can find your next job. You think about not having an income for a few weeks and about your future...
Will you be without an income soon?
You are woken up in the middle of the night by a loud noise. You are not sure what caused the noise and leave your bedroom to see what happened. You walk...
Have you been woken up in the middle of the night?

In the street you bump into an old friend you haven't seen for a long time. She is too busy to stop, so you arrange to meet later in a bar. You arrive a little late but the bar is empty and a few minutes later she is still not...
Did your friend stop?
You are eating lunch with a friend. As you start eating your salad, you describe your plans for the weekend. You accidentally drop a piece of lettuce, and your friend looks at...
Do you have salad for lunch?
You are playing basketball with some friends. While running toward the ball, you trip and scrape your knee. The scrape hurts a bit, but does not...
Are you playing soccer with your friend?

You are at the mall with your friend. While you shop, she tells you how several of her friends have recently come down with a strange illness. You think about your recent health, and wonder if you will get...
Are you shopping alone?

You are at a routine doctor's appointment. At the appointment, the doctor decides to run a few blood tests to check your health. The doctor says he will call you in a few weeks, and you will find out your test results at that...
Did you take blood test?
In the past week, how often have you felt anxious?
In the past week, when you have felt anxious, how intense or severe was your anxiety?
In the past week, how often did you avoid situations, places, objects, or activities because of anxiety or fear?
In the past week, how much did your anxiety interfere with your ability to do the things you needed to do at work, at school, or at home?
In the past week, how much did your anxiety interfere with your social life and relationships?

Over the past 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems:

Little interest or pleasure in doing things.

Over the past 2 weeks, how often have you been bothered by any of the following problems:

Feeling down, depressed, or hopeless.

The questions on the next pages will ask you about your feelings and thoughts during THE LAST MONTH. In each case, please indicate your response by choosing HOW OFTEN you felt or thought a certain way.
In the last month, how often have you felt that you were unable to control the important things in your life?
In the last month, how often have you felt confident about your ability to handle your personal problems?
In the last month, how often have you felt that things were going your way?
In the last month, how often have you felt difficulties were piling up so high that you could not overcome them?

The purpose of this quick exercise is to demonstrate what imagination-based thinking is. You will imagine what seeing, touching, and smelling a lemon is like. Please imagine this as if you are really experiencing it.

In this exercise - and throughout the training program - please remember to imagine what is happening through your own eyes, similar to the picture on the left. This is more effective than viewing the situation as an outside observer, like the picture on the right.
Okay...let's begin! Imagine you are holding the lemon in your right hand, and you can feel its shape and its weight.
Now imagine you are shining a light on the lemon, and you can see the waxy and lumpy texture of the yellow skin.
Now imagine that you scratch the skin with your fingernail, then you bring the lemon up to your nose, and you can smell the fresh zesty juice from the skin.
Now imagine that you cut the lemon in half, and you bring one half of it up for a closer look. You can see the juicy flesh in the shape of segments that look like a wagon wheel.
Now imagine that you squeeze the lemon and some of the juice squirts right into your eyes, and it is really stinging, making your eyes water.
That was the Lemon Exercise! Don't worry if you didn't experience all of the sensations strongly. This is completely normal.

In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.

Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. 

The screen will change in 20 seconds.

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation or task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Buttons: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?
What are you hoping to get out of the Hoos Think Calmly program?

Buttons: I want to think more flexibly and less negatively.
I want to be able to manage stressful situations more effectively.
I want to reduce my stress and/or anxiety.
I've learned or am currently learning from a mental healthcare provider.
I want to maintain the gains
I've made during mental health treatment.
I want to avoid a return of anxiety and/or stress I've experienced in the past.
